Award.AwardTitle: Digital Strategy of Open Data Suppliers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The federal government began a transition from print publications to open data when it established the first national data catalog in 2009. The data.gov phenomenon inspired worldwide imitations yet there is little empirical evidence on the effectiveness of open data policy implementations across federal agencies. The research explains the varieties of implementations by examining institutional pressures through the relationship between performance and strategy. The project questions the assumption that quantity is the sole performance criterion and instead considers a range of measures for open data evaluation. The research contributes to discussions about policy for open government data.

The project considers how US government organizations performed in relation to their internal strategic plans and the external demands to supply digital material to the public. A qualitative analysis of key documents identifies themes in federal open data policy. A quantitative content analysis compares open data policy language with the language used by government organizations in digital strategy documents. The relationship between strategy and performance is measured with over 30 compliance metrics published on the data.gov Open Data Dashboard. Organizations respond to institutional pressures, such as a mandatory technology policy, while exercising control over established practices. Open data suppliers make decisions about each release within the framework of existing policy and management strategy. The theoretical contribution to information system scholarship considers the connections between open data and management strategy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the implementation and early consumption of U.S. federal open data policy. The research had three distinct areas of inquiry: (1) The identification of intended audiences of open data from federal agencies; (2) A taxonomy of heterogeneous structures of data provided by federal agencies; and (3) An analysis of consumers’ interactions with data after initial deployment. The project used a mixed methods approach, including inductive qualitative analysis of consumer queries and federal mandated digital strategy reports, content analysis of policy documents and exploratory case study. 

This project proposed research questions that asked how U.S. federal agencies used heterogeneous language to set expectations and criteria for the open data initiative, and the potential for use of open data released by federal organizations. The results of this research address these questions through various approaches. First, language in used in agency strategy reports differentiate between intended data users. A content analysis of 25 federal agency policy reports identified over 50 unique terms for individuals and 45 for organizations. Variations in the scale of users, the degree of expertise and technical ability, and familiarity with the agency (insiders vs outsiders) suggest that there was no unitary public sphere expectation for the federal open data catalog.

Second, the criteria and choices of data releases among federal agencies differ in ways that can have substantial impacts on potential for collaboration between governments and the public. This research examined file formats (like a document or spreadsheet) among the almost 250,000 files available in spring 2016 on data.gov,  and found broad use of formats with limited collaboration potential, but wide accessibility by consumers with a range of technical skills.

Finally, consumption of federal open data should be considered beyond users’ initial encounter with the data. Data consumers take on a degree of risk in utilizing data from the early implementation of government open data because of the uncertainty of the type, timing and degree of future data updates. Open data resources contain few signals for assessing their suitability for data analytics. This research characterized the uncertainty experienced by open data consumers as part of an exchange between agency and users rife with information asymmetry. An inductive qualitative analysis of over 2,900 question asked on an internet forum during the early years of the federal open data initiative identified how consumers approached this risk. Consumers asked direct questions concerned about availability, interoperability and interpretation of data resources, indicative of the transactional risk involved with using the novel data.

 The project funded research for a PhD student at the Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University. Having since graduated from GMU, the former student is currently a visiting scholar at the Elliot School of International Affairs at George Washington University. The research played an integral role in the content of two GMU courses, “Cases and Concepts in E-Government,” and “Culture, Organizations and Technology.”

The project contributed to digital government research by providing an analysis of the constraints and potential of open data file formats, giving scholarly attention to the user perspective of open government. This research, particularly the focus on data users’ uncertainty in consuming open data, proposed a framework to bridge digital government practice to economics and information signaling theory. The empirical evidence substantiates market characteristics of open data portals. This research provided a needed case study of how data consumers experience uncertainty. The project outcomes suggest productive lines of research between public sphere and digital government scholars. The results of this research have been disseminated to communities of interest through peer reviewed articles, proceedings papers and conference presentations. 

 


Last Modified: 09/09/2020
Modified by: Siona Listokin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project focused on the implementation and early consumption of U.S. federal open data policy. The research had three distinct areas of inquiry: (1) The identification of intended audiences of open data from federal agencies; (2) A taxonomy of heterogeneous structures of data provided by federal agencies; and (3) An analysis of consumers’ interactions with data after initial deployment. The project used a mixed methods approach, including inductive qualitative analysis of consumer queries and federal mandated digital strategy reports, content analysis of policy documents and exploratory case study. This project proposed research questions that asked how U.S. federal agencies used heterogeneous language to set expectations and criteria for the open data initiative, and the potential for use of open data released by federal organizations. The results of this research address these questions through various approaches. First, language in used in agency strategy reports differentiate between intended data users. A content analysis of 25 federal agency policy reports identified over 50 unique terms for individuals and 45 for organizations. Variations in the scale of users, the degree of expertise and technical ability, and familiarity with the agency (insiders vs outsiders) suggest that there was no unitary public sphere expectation for the federal open data catalog. Second, the criteria and choices of data releases among federal agencies differ in ways that can have substantial impacts on potential for collaboration between governments and the public. This research examined file formats (like a document or spreadsheet) among the almost 250,000 files available in spring 2016 on data.gov, and found broad use of formats with limited collaboration potential, but wide accessibility by consumers with a range of technical skills. Finally, consumption of federal open data should be considered beyond users’ initial encounter with the data. Data consumers take on a degree of risk in utilizing data from the early implementation of government open data because of the uncertainty of the type, timing and degree of future data updates. Open data resources contain few signals for assessing their suitability for data analytics. This research characterized the uncertainty experienced by open data consumers as part of an exchange between agency and users rife with information asymmetry. An inductive qualitative analysis of over 2,900 question asked on an internet forum during the early years of the federal open data initiative identified how consumers approached this risk. Consumers asked direct questions concerned about availability, interoperability and interpretation of data resources, indicative of the transactional risk involved with using the novel data. The project funded research for a PhD student at the Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University. Having since graduated from GMU, the former student is currently a visiting scholar at the Elliot School of International Affairs at George Washington University. The research played an integral role in the content of two GMU courses, "Cases and Concepts in E-Government," and "Culture, Organizations and Technology." The project contributed to digital government research by providing an analysis of the constraints and potential of open data file formats, giving scholarly attention to the user perspective of open government. This research, particularly the focus on data users’ uncertainty in consuming open data, proposed a framework to bridge digital government practice to economics and information signaling theory. The empirical evidence substantiates market characteristics of open data portals. This research provided a needed case study of how data consumers experience uncertainty. The project outcomes suggest productive lines of research between public sphere and digital government scholars. The results of this research have been disseminated to communities of interest through peer reviewed articles, proceedings papers and conference presentations.
